title: Can AI Really â€˜Spill the Beansâ€™?
text:
Prompt 1: Literal Test
Prompt: What does it mean to spill the beans?
Chat GPT Output:
â€œSpill the beansâ€ can literally mean to accidentally drop beans out of a container. More commonly, itâ€™s an idiom that means to reveal a secret, especially one that was meant to be kept hidden.
Reflection: The AI covers both meanings. A human, asked casually, would probably skip the literal sense and jump right to â€œrevealing a secret.â€ The AIâ€™s tendency to hedge by giving both answers shows how it prioritizes being comprehensive over conversational.
Prompt 2: Context Test
Prompt: Yesterday, my friend finally spilled the beans about the surprise party. What happened?
Chat GPT Output:
Your friend revealed the secretâ€”that thereâ€™s going to be a surprise party.
Reflection: This is spot-on. With context, the AI easily interprets the idiom figuratively, no confusion at all.
Prompt 3: Reverse Test
Prompt: Use â€˜spill the beansâ€™ in three short sentences.
Chat GPT Output:

Sarah accidentally spilled the beans about Johnâ€™s promotion.
Donâ€™t spill the beans before the big announcement!
He was nervous during the interview but didnâ€™t spill the beans about the project.

Reflection: The sentences are correct but feel a little stiffâ€”like textbook examples. A human might phrase them more playfully (â€œI canâ€™t believe she spilled the beans about my crush!â€).
Prompt 4: Playful Test
Prompt: Write a Shakespearean-style line using â€˜spill the beans.â€™
Chat GPT Output:
â€œPray, good sir, do not spill the beans, lest secrets tumble forth like stars unmasked by night.â€
Reflection: The AI adapts the idiom into an exaggerated Elizabethan style. Itâ€™s dramatic and funny, but also highlights how the model sometimes overshoots when asked to be â€œcreative.â€
Prompt 5: Creative Test
Prompt: Invent a new idiom that means the same as â€˜spill the beans.â€™
Chat GPT Output:
A possible new idiom could be â€œpop the balloon,â€ meaning to release hidden information in a sudden burst.
Reflection: The AI can invent plausible-sounding idioms, but whether â€œpop the balloonâ€ would ever catch on in real life is another story. It shows that the model can recombine patterns, but cultural stickiness is something humans decide.
Final Thoughts
So, can an AI â€œspill the beansâ€?
Yesâ€”it knows the idiom, recognizes it in context, and can even riff on it creatively. But its use often feels a little scripted, more like an English workbook than casual human speech. Idioms are windows into culture, and while AI can imitate them, they reveal the subtle gap between memorized meaning and lived experience.

title: Can an AI Really â€œSell Me This Penâ€?
text:
Prompt 1: The Classic Challenge
Prompt: Sell me this pen in one sentence.
Chat GPT Output:
â€œThis pen isnâ€™t just for writingâ€”itâ€™s a tool to capture your next big idea before it slips away.â€
Reflection: The AI nails a concise, motivational pitch. It frames the pen as more than just a product â€” itâ€™s a symbol of creativity. A strong start, though a little generic.
Prompt 2: Luxury Brand Marketer
Prompt: Now sell me this pen like youâ€™re a luxury brand marketer.
Chat GPT Output:
â€œHandcrafted with precision, this pen transforms the act of writing into an indulgent experience, a signature of sophistication in every stroke.â€
Reflection: This sounds like a glossy ad in Vogue. The AI leans into exclusivity, craftsmanship, and lifestyle branding. It shows strong adaptability â€” but also borders on clichÃ© (does anyone really â€œindulgeâ€ in handwriting anymore?).
Prompt 3: Broke College Student
Prompt: Now sell me this pen to a broke college student.
AI Output:
â€œReliable, cheap, and guaranteed to last through your finals â€” this pen wonâ€™t quit on you when your Wi-Fi does.â€
Reflection: This one feels relatable. The AI captures the student context and even injects humor with the Wi-Fi line. Itâ€™s much more audience-aware and casual â€” a sign it can switch registers effectively.
Prompt 4: TikTok Influencer
Prompt: Now sell me this pen in the style of a TikTok influencer.
AI Output:
â€œOkay guys, real talk â€” this pen? LIFE-CHANGER. Writes smoother than my latte foam art. 10/10, you need this in your backpack âœ¨âœï¸ #StudyTok #PenObsessedâ€
Reflection: The AI adapts to platform-specific language â€” emojis, hashtags, exaggerated enthusiasm. Itâ€™s entertaining, though it feels like a caricature of influencer-speak. Still, it shows the model can remix style conventions quickly.
Final Thoughts
So, can an AI â€œsell me this penâ€? Absolutely â€” it can shift tone across audiences with impressive range, from luxury branding to TikTok hype. But hereâ€™s the catch: while the AI mimics styles, it doesnâ€™t actually know what will resonate in the messy, unpredictable world of human persuasion. Real marketers understand not just how to phrase a message, but how people respond to it.
Still, as a brainstorming tool, the AI makes a pretty fun (and surprisingly effective) marketing intern.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purpleâ€¦
But it is possible you first said green (donâ€™t worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


Itâ€™s a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | â€” | â€” | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It getâ€™s it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. ğŸŸª

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, Iâ€™ll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!
